Award.AwardTitle: The MAMMS Project: Measuring and Addressing Middle-Grades Misconceptions in Statistics

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: This 3 year project was initially submitted to the ITEST program, but was deemed more appropriate to the DRK-12 assessment strand. The project seeks to develop diagnostic assessments to identify specific statistical misconceptions (datasets as entities, comparing datasets, and overreliance on the mean procedure), teacher tutorials to bolster and reinforce teachers? understandings of these concepts and misconceptions, activities to engage students in applications of statistical reasoning including supplemental activities for individualized instruction, and an efficacy trial to evaluate the effect of the resources on students? knowledge and affect in statistics. They will use cognitive labs to address validity and a randomized control trial to address initial efficacy. Teacher pre-activity tutorials and student activities will be made freely and publicly available.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Strong statistical reasoning and data analysis skills are essential to function in an increasingly data-driven world. In everyday life, media is filled with data that is open to analysis and interpretation. Across a range of career types, both in STEM fields and in other fields, professionals are expected to work with data relevant to their field. The demand for statisticians and data scientists continues to grow. Advanced statistical reasoning is grounded in fundamental understandings, including conceptual foundations about data. To support the development of this kind of reasoning, students should be engaged in statistical thinking throughout elementary, middle, and high school. It is imperative to develop statistical understandings with young students to prepare and inspire them for future education and career opportunities. Unfortunately, students continue to struggle with statistics at all levels, often developing persistent misunderstandings that are resistant to instruction. Further, students often have a negative affect towards statistics.

To begin to address this reality, the Diagnostic Statistics Assessment (DSA) project developed resources to help support the teaching and learning of statistics in the middle grades, with the goal of improving students? understanding of statistical concepts and attitudes towards statistics. The DSA built upon prior successes in using formative, diagnostic assessment systems to improve math knowledge in the middle grades and used the approach of targeting specific misconceptions to identify the source of students? difficulty. The assessment system also included instructional resources, which were developed to promote more effective instruction, improve student learning, and improve student attitudes towards statistics in the middle grades.

The DSA developed a system that includes short, diagnostic assessments designed to be administered during instruction. The assessments were designed to identify students reasoning with three targeted misconceptions. The misconceptions were selected from prior research and relate to interpreting a data distribution as a single entity, comparing data distributions, and an overreliance on the mean procedure/formula without a deeper statistical and mathematical understanding of what the mean means. The DSA system also includes resources for teachers and students. Teacher tutorials were designed to help teachers understand the targeted misconceptions and other key concepts related to statistical investigations. Classroom activities were designed to engage students in realistic applications of the statistical reasoning process, with the goal of supporting and improving statistical understanding and attitude. The activities also contain components designed to specifically address misconception reasoning identified by the assessments. The teacher tutorials and classroom activities are currently freely available.

A randomized controlled trial using a pre-post design was conducted to evaluate the effect of using the DSA resources on student knowledge and attitude. The results of an analysis using hierarchical linear modeling indicate that, after accounting for pre-test scores, students whose teachers had access to the DSA resources selected significantly more correct responses and significantly fewer misconception responses on the DSA assessments compared to students whose teachers did not have access to the DSA resources. The effect sizes ranged from medium to large.

There was not a statistically significant difference in the attitude toward statistics held by students whose teachers did and did not have access to the DSA resources. However, there were some significant differences in specific aspects of attitude for some students: sixth and seventh grade students? self-confidence related to statistics and eight grade students? perception of the value of statistics. These result highlights the difficulty of changing ingrained attitudes towards statistics, while also showing that changing attitudes is possible. The results also support the development of resources for students at even younger grades, to help prevent the development of negative attitudes, rather than trying to remediate those attitudes in the middle grades.

The DSA project developed instructional resources that helped to improve student understanding and reduce student misconceptions. The resources also improved some aspects of some students? attitudes toward statistics. The DSA project will continue to have an impact on the statistical knowledge and attitude of students and teachers through the continued availability of the DSA resources, which will ultimately help support students in developing the necessary prerequisite knowledge and attitude needed to adequately reason in a data-laden world and to potentially pursue future education and careers in STEM fields.
